title: Should I send a second email? I requested a recommendation letter from a former professor. He ignores my email. Its been 4 days. In fact, he should reply even if he doesn’t want to write. Ignorance is rude. I was an A student. - Quora

response.answer_text: [A2A] First, the professor does not owe you a recommendation letter, and they certainly do not owe you a response in less than four days. They could be overwhelmed by other more immediate teaching, research, and service tasks, or by a family/legal/financial/political crisis. They could be traveling, or sick, or depressed, or retired, or dead. They could have a policy of only considering requests for recommendation letters that are made in person, or by students who made an A+, or by students who have done more with them than take one class. Your email could have been classified as spam, perhaps because you sent it from a non-university email address. They might be doing their own background research, in parallel with all their other work, before deciding how to respond. They might have seen that you didn’t include important details in your request, like where you’re applying and why, and written you off as not serious. They might have objected to the tone of your request and written you off as a jerk. Or they might just have a hard time telling people no. If the professor still hasn’t answered within a week or so, it would be reasonable to send a second request, or better yet, to stop by their office in person and ask them (or their assistant) for an appointment to discuss your request in person. If they still don’t reply, take the hint. Ask someone else.

The way your question is written suggests the very reason you don’t have a letter of recommendation. If you want a busy professional to take time to do something important for you, be humble and have some gratitude. Contact the front desk administrator to find out when the professor is free, ideally you aren’t asking at midterms, during finals or over break. Ask permission to speak to the professor. See the professor when they allow it. If they don’t show any interest in your request because your classes with them were a number of years ago, move on. Provide all the necessary information needed to write this letter, craft a rough draft for them. Provide enough time for them to give it consideration and return it to you. Less than two weeks time is pushing it. Thank them for their assistance, and listening to your request. Tell them you appreciate their time and efforts to help you. In the future you make this arrangement before class finalizes and have chance to ask them face to face. Sending a gimmee gimmee email is lame.

You have received some good advice in this thread and you should sit and think about what you are being told for a while. But, I’m going to answer your question honestly, despite it’s obvious problems. Yes, you should follow up. Unless you are one of my current students who get very quick responses, I may or may not answer your email within four days depending on what was going on at the time, whether I remembered you and for what reasons, whether I was interrupted the moment I was about to click reply, and so on. It’s not personal, but it’s the reality of the situation. Not only am I busy like everyone else, I don’t expect that anyone I’m not currently involved with in a class, a project, or some other timely business to have urgent requests. If you wrote a polite follow-up four or five days later, it would remind me that your email is there, that it likely got buried in my inbox, and that it mattered to you. Maybe I didn’t even see it to begin with, which is rare but happens. If I got that follow-up email, I’d respond within the next day or two. If I didn’t, it meant that something really important is happening or that I was pointedly ignoring you because I can (also both rare occurrences, but happens). My response would be the standard, here are my terms for writing letters of recommendation, etc., which is worth pointing out that I’m never required to do and places a substantial burden on my time because my letters are highly personalized to be effective. I write letters of recommendation for deserving students who demonstrate significant potential *and* who make my job as a letter writer as easy as possible, not students who get As. These letters always speak directly to the character, attitude, and emotional maturity of the candidate in addition to their intellectual potential and professional work. You want to make it easy for me to write great things.

I hope this is a troll, I'll answer as if you are real. You are welcome. You might send a second email though 4 days may not be enough response time. Your attitude is rude and condescending. The word ignorance is used incorrectly. So, you may not be as grand as you see yourself. Professors usually like to write letters of recommendations for students who are appreciative and make them look good. If you handle most situations with the same self absorbed arrogance that you displayed in this question, you probably are not that student. A professors ONLY obligation to his students is to provide and opportunity to learn which you obviously did if you actually earned and A. Congratulations. If he actually does write you an.letter if recommendation, try being thankful. Graciousness goes a long way in life.

So many problems with your question. Sense of the order of the universe: you are not the center of your professor’s universe. He does not owe you an instant response. He has professional obligations (teaching) and, perhaps, a family. How did you make your request? Did you include a current resume and the exact name and address of the person to whom the letter should be addressed? Is this for a job? Did you include the job posting? Have you had an in-person conversation with your professor about why you want the job and how your class work supports your request? Is this for grad school? Does the professor understand why you are interested in the particular program? Have you EVER met with this professor? If all that he knows about you is that you got an A, the letter will be thin. Transparently thin. I suggest that you call the professor’s secretary to make sure that he is all right, and not in the middle of a family or medical emergency, which might make your tantrum even more embarrassing. I hope, also, that you weren’t in need of a 24-hour turnaround on this request. There are very few circumstances under which a letter of recommendation request is reasonable on the same sort of timeline as Instant Rice.

Two considerations 1st “I was an A student” professors have had thousands of A Students, so that is not going to move a professor who has probably 4 classes they are teaching this semester, they probably have several requests from students for meetings, and, it is highly likely this professor has a family. You are not the only person in this professors life that is sending emails. Part of college is to become mature and see the world around you from another perspective.

response.answer_text: Wait a week. At least a full work week. A 2nd email reminder won’t hurt. My advice to you is to calm down. You’re being hypercritical of him and you don’t know the situation. Maybe he’s on vacation or he /family member is sick. This is a good lesson for the rest of your life. Generally, if you don’t have enough information—assume people do the best they can and don’t take such happenings personal. BYW: congratulations on your hard work and grades. Where did you go? What was your major?

While I have a personal ethic to respond within a day to everyone who requests a letter from me, I understand that many do not share this conviction. So, I am not sure that there should be an expectation for response - or even a letter. I have counseled a number of proteges (students, fellow professionals, job seekers) that one should never rely on just the required number of letters of reference. In other words, if you need three, ask six people. Provide pre-addressed stamped envelopes, e-mail addresses, web sites… whatever is needed to make it easier for the person you’re asking. Yes, you may want to follow up with a polite e-mail to your professor, but don’t expect any response. Just keep asking other professors, current and former employers, project leaders, and even fellow students. Personal references are often OK, too. For at least one of mine, I had a state legislator complete one for me.

response.answer_text: Does the professor have a sabbatical or something? Early term activity might have put this on the back burner. Can you visit the department? Four days isn’t an eternity. Does he/she know your deadline? Wait till it’s a week and try a little indirect stuff first. You don’t want to press someone too hard for voluntary work. You do want an answer. In any followup, your timetable should be clear, too.

response.answer_text: You can email again, and if he doesn’t respond again you should really consider asking someone else. Moreover, Ignoring your email is not rude. It is the standard way of telling you to piss off in academia, and those who bother to politely decline are saints.

You might not like this, but home truths can be uncomfortable. If you were this judgmental and showed this sense of entitlement in his class, there's a good reason he's ignoring you and it would be in your best interests to help him forget you, lest he start providing references you won't like.
